ygData.subject: New ES-HyperNEAT Website and Publications Available
ygData.msgSnippet: Sebastian Risi and I are pleased to announce the new ES-HyperNEAT Users Page, as well as new publications on the method.  The ability of HyperNEAT to evolve

Subject: New ES-HyperNEAT Website and Publications Available
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=e_vQeYldP-5zHFGvbing2uWPYIgl3qw2Y4DdExkyg5Dde6Hyqlzt

Sebastian Risi and I are pleased to announce the new ES-HyperNEAT Users Pag=
e, as well as new publications on the method.  The ability of HyperNEAT to =
evolve the placement and density of nodes on the substrate has long been de=
sired by HyperNEAT users and researchers, and we are hoping with these reso=
urces to make it easier to incorporate such a capability into the algorithm=
.

The new ES-HyperNEAT Users Page is at 

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/ESHyperN=
EAT/ 

and includes an overview of the algorithm, answers to frequent quest=
ions, and links to papers and software (including ES-HyperNEAT source code =
that is now available in C#).  

A complete, comprehensive introduction to =
the method with several experiments is also now available in our new journa=
l article, "An Enhanced Hypercube-Based Encoding for Evolving the Placement=
, Density and Connectivity of Neurons," to appear in Artficial Life journal=
.  The manuscript is at:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_alife12.pdf

=
Finally, we are also happy to announce our forthcoming IJCNN paper, "A Unif=
ied Approach to Evolving Plasticity and Neural Geometry," which combines ES=
-HyperNEAT with adaptive HyperNEAT to produce a system that can evolve the =
geometry, placement, density, and plasticity of an adaptive neural network:=


http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/risi_ijcnn12.pdf

This work aims to move o=
ne step closer to evolving more brain-like structures.  

We are happy of c=
ourse to answer any questions as well.

ken
